posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Let's not forget that "deviates from the game" is more often than not an excuse to conceal a bigoted opinion. The original material isn't sacred texts or something. It's good, and no matter what adaptation is made of it, it will carry on existing, but adaptations do not need to be 1:1 up to the absurd. Especially if made by one of the original creators. All creatives will tell you if they had the opportunity to revisit something they made, they would probably change some stuff.

In general, people with such bigoted opinions are not that upfront, as they don't want to be called out, so they will hide behind things like biology, historical accuracy etc. A classic example I like to point at is Game of Throne. Some people complained that there were too many female lead roles, unrealistic according to them, given the medieval context. It's not a direct jab at feminism and so-called "woke culture", even though it really is that in the end, but it is hidden behind an historial question. A funny one, considering GoT isn't even trying to be historically accurate.

This episode of TLOU deviates a bit from the game, for sure. However, as you said it does not fundamentally change the story. It also paints a secondary character under a much more human light than the game. Originally, Bill is your good old survivalist, with a "fuck you" attitude. Quite a common trope in post-apocalyptic flicks. The TV shows makes him a lot more interesting & subtle. If anything, I wish this was the game's Bill.

We were warned certain things would be different from the game in the TV show. If that's the kind of deviations we get, I'm happy with that. It improves the Last of Us' universe, without taking anything away from it.

>>179971905
I agree with most of your points. In particular, I hope the shows keeps making changes in world-building and character, as long as the visual identity overall stays the same and the ending isn't modified. As you say, the original story isn't going anywhere. If you don't take creative risks, what's the point of even adapting anything? You'd just be admitting the story was already perfect and probably better suited to stay on the previous medium.

However, I feel that this episode had no place taking up so much screetime with a side-story that, while sweet and well-shot, contributes nothing to overall plot or character development barring a car, some MC interactions and a letter. It gives a lot to Bill as a character and creates a completely new Frank, but doesn't give the rest of the story more than the original game did. The season is going to be tight enough already and I will remember this episode later on if there are problems with pacing or the Joel/Ellie relationship feels forced. This could have been 10 minutes long or an anthology episode in a spin-off in-between-seasons show, in my opinion at least.

Other than that I'm curious as to how this will affect viewership. It certainly got the show some attention apparently, but will casual fans keep watching after an episode with no Infected at all? I guess the next episode will be Pittsburgh so the violence in that will balance it and probably be a defining point in how the series is perceived from then on.

Their evolutionary strategy is now "I taste good, human help me reproduce", no different than plants with fruit that are tasty so birds shit out the seeds. So face the reality. You're an omnivore, the livestock benefits from being eaten, it's a far better arrangement than if they were eaten by a wolf or bear.

>>179971120
I would have to vehemently disagree.

The first thing I think that needs to be considered is who in canon actually wants to date Harry. In the books Harry mostly experiences interest from Ginny, Cho, Pavarti, and Romalda. In the movies a case can be made that sexual/romantic tension exists between Harry/Hermione or Harry/Luna. In the books and movies, as far as what is cannon, these girls are the only ones who make any sense because they are the only ones who want to date Harry back. Someone like Tonks or Katie or Fleur never express interest. In your own fanfiction you can certainly change that but in canon, these six are the only ones shown to want to date Harry back at any time. Any others are faceless gigglers to Harry.

We don’t really learn much about what Harry finds physically attractive, but instead be tend to find out who he finds attractive. In a physical sense his descriptions of Hermione are mostly neutral in the books. Frissy haired, buck toothed, etc. Luna also experiences similar treatment. While his judgements aren’t harsh, they don’t speak to deep attraction. Protuberant eyes as a description is not flattering. What we do learn is that Harry likes shiny hair. Our best insights into what Harry actually finds physically attractive is found in his musings on Ginny and Cho. He likes athletes. He likes shiny hair.

Harry’s humor seems to fit the Weasley model the best. Of the six girls to express interest, we know little about Pavarti, Romelda, and Cho’s humor. We do know that Harry has a similar love for pranks as Ginny. Harry is often uncertain if Luna is joking or not, and finds more things humorous than Hermione. The best fit for Harry’s humor is Ginny.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>179971146
Most of Harry’s hobbies are ones he can share with Ron. Ron introduced him to wizarding hobbies. Quidditch, chess, exploding snap, chocolate frog card collecting, etc. We know Ginny and Cho play Quidditch. We also see Ginny participating in these other pastimes. Hermione is show to like reading and knitting. Luna’s hobbies tend to be art, animals, or journalistic. Parvati is linked with Lavender in liking traditionally feminine things like makeup and gossip. We know Romelda is untalented at quidditch from the tryouts in book six. While some of the girls we can’t rule out sharing interests with Harry, the obvious stated front runner is Ginny.

As far as understanding Harry and the trauma he has experienced, it is clear that Harry and Cho didn’t intuitively know how to comfort one another or help with each others trauma. Ginny, Hermione, and Luna all at different points help Harry when he is emotional to overcome some of his trauma, and are helped by Harry. Hermione has the best understanding of what Harry has been through. Ginny has the best understanding of Harry’s relationship with Voldemort and the self doubt that causes. Luna has the best understanding of Harry’s grief. The other two don’t demonstrate an understanding of Harry.

It is easily to rule out Pavarti and Romelda at this point. It makes sense for Harry to date any of the other four witches. Based on canon he could hve a functional relationship with any of them post war. Still, I think of the established characters who have a potential interest in Harry, Ginny makes the most sense.

>>179971603
Nah don't be a retard, it's just the typical thing they say, "the author was greatly involved in the production" is just a marketing trick.

Oda took a 1 month break to work this summer to work on the final saga, I think he made a trip to see the set but in practice, he's got enough on his plate with the manga, bonus materials like color pages, and animated movies. Jump even consented to slow down the publication of OP because it's their golden goose and they don't want to risk Oda's health. There's just no time to work on a tv show, let alone one that will be produced and directed in another continent, in another timezone entirely, with all the language barriers and schedule issues this entail.

He gave them his blessing and probably get to keep an eye on some stuff in exchange for shilling the show when it comes out, but I doubt he has any actual veto power or that he cares about it any more than he cares about the anime, and considering how poor OP's anime has been at time it's clearly not his priority (or even his job at all)

>>179971035
The film opens with the genesis of the rage virus. Precisely 28 days later, Jim wakes up to a different world. He meets Mark and Selena who take him back home the next day. Mark is then killed that evening, and Jim and Selena seek shelter at Frank and Hannah's apartment. Frank says that the trip to the blockade could take about 2-3 days. The trip takes roughly 2. Frank is killed, and the soldiers take in Jim, Selena and Hannah. We're right around 31-32 days after the initial outbreak.
Major West tells Jim "8 days ago I found Jones with a gun in his mouth. He said he was going to kill himself because there is no future." This of course is when it is revealed the soldiers' broadcast is all about luring women.
So here's what I realized:
Let's say there's 32 days since the initial infection at this point. Obviously the infection did not take out England in one whole day since there had to be enough time for people to put up the pictures/letters in the public square and for newspapers to announce an evacuation. So, even if that all occurred within one day (and it's far more feasible that it occurred over a couple), that still leaves about 3 weeks between the infection actually doing major damage to England and Jones' attempt at suicide.
This means only three weeks passed before the soldiers turned rapist. It took only about 20 days (give or take) for them broadcast a lure for women.

>>179972422
The letter Bill leaves to Joel is the purpose of the entire tangent. Bill and Frank's story is meant to illustrate the two things that Joel needs to understand: one right at that moment when he reads the letter and decides to take Ellie to Wyoming, which is that there are still things worth fighting for in the world, and the second in the end, when he decides to save Ellie from the Fireflies, which is that those things must always be personal and it's worth opening yourself up to the possibility of hurt in order to achieve those things. Without having seen Bill learn those things with Frank over the course of 20 years of apocalypse, we as the audience won't have nearly as much of an insight into the dilemma that Joel needs to resolve in himself as he's reading the letter. It's because of this "filler" that his choice becomes as impactful as it is.

Game Bill vs Show Bill are the exact opposite.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
wasting my time on this mongolian basket weaving forum but the whole point of the change is that in the game, bill is supposed to be a shipwreck of a character. he exists entirely to showcase what joel was heading towards as an embittered obese hyper autismo who hates everything, hates himself, and exists only to pursue his own survival instinct, much like the infection. you receive the last glimpses of his humanity in that he does pay back what he owes, and bitterly mourns what he's lost, but that's the end for him. it's a speed bump on a redemptionless road.

now that works for the game, but i like the recontextualization of the show bill. instead of a cautionary tale, we get the opposite. this survivalist who trusted no one and was extremely paranoid cracked and let his emotional defenses down, and loved somebody when it was absolutely inevitable that this would kill him emotionally in the end. and it did and didn't. somehow they muddled through, and they turned the tragedy that they were facing down into the happiest ending that they could get in a fucked up world.

that's joel's light at the end of the tunnel, and i think this positive motivation rather than a negative motivation will give joel's hospital rampage much more pathos at the end. also they probably didn't want to make it a video game section where joel, ellie, and bill wade through a bunch of infected because that's not as effective for an emotional journey narrative

>>179974093
Noir refers to crime, mystery and drama films that use symbolism and visuals to suggest things that the Hays production code would not allow. It's a genre that exists because filmmakers were forced to "tone down" their movies and make them more family friendly, but found creative ways to get around this and still make adult-oriented movies. This is why noir movies made after the fall of the production code are "neo noir" and not "classic noir"
